 Here is a simple breakdown of the problem with illegal immigration and what we can do to alleviate it.
 
 
 Problems with illegal immigration
 Each year, 3 million people are coming over here illegally, 3 times the number of people who come here legally and go through the long and drawn out process. Companies would prefer, with our very loose enforcement of the laws, to hire someone for cheaper. Someone here illegally is willing to work for $2 an hour because they will pay no taxes, but somehere here legally, who has to pay taxes, can't afford to make $2 an hour. This encourages illegals to break the rules and come here because they will benefit more than if they receive US citizenship and have to pay taxes. There are approximately 15 million illegals in the US right now. Since they don't pay taxes, how do they get healthcare, housing, and education for them and their children? The government, in the form of our taxes, pays for this. Another problem is the overcrowding we face without the illegals. Many jails are close to their limits. With 3 million illegals making it across and over 1 million being caught each year, we simply don't have the room to put them in our jails, only to have them sent back to Mexico and try again. When they are thrown in jail, they are given a public defender, which you and I are paying for, and they are taken care of with our tax dollars in prison. They are sent back to Mexico and try again, and we continue to go through this endless cycle until the finally get over here, and we still end up paying for them. We are trying to give those who we catch plane tickets to southern Mexico. TIME interviewed several of those apprehended and they said they will just try again in a week. This is no deterrent whatsoever.
 
 
 Solutions to combat illegal immigration
 There are a few solutions to help limit illegal immigration. We can construct an enormous wall to keep them from coming over, which will be expensive, controversial, and probably be fought tooth and nail by the ACLU. Another option is to place more National Guard troops on the border, which will be at an astronomical cost and will require thousands of troops, which will also take away our ability to station troops overseas. I think the best solution is to severely enforce our current laws and punish any and all corporations who continue to hire illegals to the fullest extent. I think the temporary worker program will be a nice complement to the strict enforcement of our current laws. Mexicans will be able to register to get a temporary worker card, and when farmers, for instance, need work and are having trouble finding workers, they call the organization in charge of the program and request workers. This way, illegals have no reason to want to come here if they can't find a job and won't be taken care of by us taxpayers. We should also encourage those who want to move to America to do so legally. Those who are doing that now are being punished for following the law because we are having to limit the number we can allow in the US each year because of the outrageous number of illegals who come here. It only makes sense that if we strictly enforce our current laws we will drastically reduce the illegals who come here. We need to also cut off any and all public services to those illegals who continue to come here, and as soon as we find them, we should deport them back to Mexico. As it is now, they simply try again because they know if they get across they'll get a job. But if we enforce the laws and deport those illegals who we find here, they will eventually get the picture that they won't be taken care of here at the expense of us taxpayers and that they cannot get employed here.
